title: Example Data Analysis Using Gapminder Dataset
text:
For this analysis, I am using the Gapminder dataset, which contains data about life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population across different countries and continents over time.


How does life expectancy vary with GDP per capita across different continents?



This analysis is intended for policy makers, public health researchers, and general public who are interested in understanding the impact of economic factors on health outcomes.



The dataset comes from the Gapminder Foundation and is available through the gapminder R package. - Original dataset: Gapminder Dataset - Data Dictionary: - `country`: Name of the country - `continent`: Continent where the country is located - `year`: Year of observation - `lifeExp`: Life expectancy at birth (in years) - `gdpPercap`: GDP per capita (in USD) - `pop`: Population size






Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


# A tibble: 142 × 7
   country          continent  year lifeExp gdpPercap       pop gdp_log
   <fct>            <fct>     <int>   <dbl>     <dbl>     <int>   <dbl>
 1 Japan            Asia       2007    82.6    31656. 127467972    10.4
 2 Hong Kong, China Asia       2007    82.2    39725.   6980412    10.6
 3 Iceland          Europe     2007    81.8    36181.    301931    10.5
 4 Switzerland      Europe     2007    81.7    37506.   7554661    10.5
 5 Australia        Oceania    2007    81.2    34435.  20434176    10.4
 6 Spain            Europe     2007    80.9    28821.  40448191    10.3
 7 Sweden           Europe     2007    80.9    33860.   9031088    10.4
 8 Israel           Asia       2007    80.7    25523.   6426679    10.1
 9 France           Europe     2007    80.7    30470.  61083916    10.3
10 Canada           Americas   2007    80.7    36319.  33390141    10.5
# ℹ 132 more rows














`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'




















Note: Higher GDP per capita is often associated with increased life expectancy, indicating the importance of economic stability for health.


Tip: Policy interventions that focus on economic growth may also contribute to improved health outcomes.




The analysis of the Gapminder data reveals that life expectancy tends to be higher in continents with higher average GDP per capita. Additionally, countries with larger populations tend to exhibit a diverse range of life expectancies. This analysis highlights the importance of both economic and demographic factors in determining health outcomes.









Health and Wealth



Countries with higher GDP per capita generally enjoy better health outcomes, emphasizing the importance of economic development.






Gapminder Foundation. “Gapminder Data.” Link
Rosling, Hans. “Factfulness: Ten Reasons We’re Wrong About the World.” 2018.
OECD. “Health at a Glance 2019: OECD Indicators.” Link







select(), filter(), mutate(), arrange() ### ggplot2
geom_boxplot(), geom_point(), geom_smooth(), facet_wrap()

title: Yimin Ding’s Website
text:
Welcome!
Hello! My name is Yimin Ding, and you can call me Minnie, the same name as the wife of Mickey Mouse, lol. Like Minnie, I love baking and doing sports exercises.
Here is a picture of desserts I made:



Steamed Cake

title: About Yimin Ding
text:
I am a seocond-year MHS student studying in epidemiology in cardiovascular track. I graduated from Tulane University with an interest switching from infectious disease to chronic disease. My primary interest is relating CVD risk factor to physical activity and sleeping hours. Having a strong passion for improving health outcomes, particularly for aging populations, I enjoy bridging the gap between complex data analysis and real-world applications through using evidence-based data analysis.



Preferred name given by my mum, who thought I would be happy since I love the character Micky Mouse, however, she would never know that my facourite name is Lizzy, the nickname of Elizabeth in Pride and Prejudice.
Starting swimming with the hope of keeping myself from getting hurt, but still having my bones broken and badly twisted more than 10 times.
Being named Cheese by my friend, but I hate eating cheese except shredded one.

title: Student Data Analysis
text:
Code
# Part 3: Student Data Analysis in Shell

# Download the students.csv file using wget
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/bin:$PATH"
/opt/homebrew/bin/wget https://github.com/stephaniehicks/jhustatprogramming2024/blob/main/projects/01-project/students.csv

# Display the contents of the students.csv file
cat students.csv

# Display only the first 5 lines of the file
head -n 5 students.csv

# Display the last 3 lines of the file
tail -n 3 students.csv

# Count the number of lines in the file
wc -l students.csv

# Find students taking Math as a subject
grep 'Math' students.csv

# Find all female students
grep ',F,' students.csv

# Sort by Age in ascending order
sort -t',' -k3 -n students.csv

# Find unique subjects
cut -d',' -f6 students.csv | sort | uniq

# Calculate the average grade
awk -F',' '{if(NR>1) sum+=$5; count+=1} END {print "Average Grade:", sum/(count-1)}' students.csv

# Replace Math with Mathematics
sed 's/Math/Mathematics/g' students.csv

title: Reflection on Building a Brand as a Scientist
text:
The blog post “Building a Brand as a Scientist” by Stephanie Hicks really impressed me with how important it is to realize what I want my professional identity to be. One question that stood out to me was, “What do I want to be known for?” I want to be recognized as a scientist who makes data understandable and actionable, especially in the field of public health. I believe in the power of data to bring about positive change, and I want to use my skills to improve community health outcomes and promote evidence-based decision-making.
Another aspect that resonated with me was how we need to identify our audience. My audience includes both scientific peers and the general public. I want to communicate science in a way that breaks down barriers, making complex ideas more accessible, especially among aging people. By doing so, I aim to bridge the gap between academic research and public understanding, inspiring informed discussions on health and well-being.
